qas.question: Which governor is given credit for the name Tennessee as it is now spelled?
Which work by Henry Timberlake made the current spelling of Tennessee widely popular?
Which state created a county called Tennessee in 1788?
Which two Tennessee counties cover the area that comprised North Carolina's Tennessee County?
In which year did a constitutional convention meet to form a new state out of the unincorporated territory that would become Tennessee?

context: The modern spelling, Tennessee, is attributed to <a0_0>James Glen<a0_0/>, the governor of South Carolina, who used this spelling in his official correspondence during the 1750s. The spelling was popularized by the publication of Henry Timberlake's "<a1_0>Draught of the Cherokee Country<a1_0/>" in 1765. In 1788, <a2_0>North Carolina<a2_0/> created "Tennessee County", the third county to be established in what is now Middle Tennessee. (Tennessee County was the predecessor to current-day <a3_0>Montgomery County and Robertson County<a3_0/>.) When a constitutional convention met in <a4_0>1796<a4_0/> to organize a new state out of the Southwest Territory, it adopted "Tennessee" as the name of the state.
